newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong's Hang Lung seen reporting flat profit.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong's Hang Lung seen reporting flat profit.

text.p: Residential property developer Hang Lung Development Ltd is expected to announce sluggish earnings for the year ended June 30, slowed by a thin land bank and a dependence on sites with less demand, analysts said.
The Hong Kong developer is expected to announce zero to single-digit percentage growth in earnings for the year ended June 30, analysts said.
Hang Lung will release its results on Friday alongside its 57.6 percent held subsidiary Amoy Properties Ltd and 60.62 percent held Grand Hotel Holdings Ltd.
"The company failed to replenish its landbank during the downturn in the market," says Adrian Ngan, property analyst at Peregrine Securities.
"The projects (and sites) that it has on hand are not sufficient to sustain earnings growth in the long-term."
Analysts said the company's concentration of residential development projects outside Hong Kong's urban core in the New Territories district, where an oversupply is forecast, was another negative.
Carol Lai, research manager at Amsteel Securities Research Ltd, said Hang Lung's projects were located in Tuen Mun, Tai Po and Maanshan, where other large developers have major projects.

Because of its small landbank and limited number of projects, Hang Lung is the only residential property developer to book profits on a percentage of completion basis in stages before a project are fully completed.

"Hang Lung is the hardest (developer) to gauge because it uses the percentage of completion basis, said Lai. Most other developers book profits after a project is completed and a government occupation permit is received.
Hang Lung reported net profit of HK$2.16 billion (US$279 million) in the year ended June 1995, up 6.88 percent from the previous year.
Amsteel is forecasting earnings growth of 5.2 percent for Hang Lung for 1996 and a pick up to 13 percent in 1997.
Peregrine's Ngan is forecasting flat earnings growth to HK$2.167 billion for the company in 1996.
For 1997, Ngan said he expected the company to show a 16.7 percent decline in earnings, subject to upward revision if 1996 prices for flats look firmer than forecast, he said.
Given the 1997 forecast and despite the share's low valuation of only 8.96 times historic, Ngan said the share was fairly valued and recommended a sell.
Since the bulk of Hang Lung's assets are in subsidiary Amoy, the company's shares always trade at a deeper discount to the market than other developers, Ngan said.
"Only when we see a greater discrepancy (in valuations) open up between Amoy and Hang Lung will we see Hang Lung move up," he added.
Hang Lung shares fell HK$0.05 to HK$15.10 on Wednesday.
